docs.title: About React Native Reanimated
docs.description: This is a documentation website of Reanimated 2 stable release.

docs.title: Animations
docs.description: Animations are first-class citizens in Reanimated 2.

docs.title: cancelAnimation
docs.description: Starts a time-based animation.

docs.title: measure
docs.description: Determines the location on screen, width, and height of the given view. Note that these measurements are not available until after the rendering has been completed in native. If you need the measurements as soon as possible, consider using onLayout instead.

docs.title: scrollTo
docs.description: Provides synchronous scroll on the UI thread to a given offset using an animated ref to a scroll view. This allows performing smooth scrolling without lags(which might occur when it would be asynchronous and based on a lot of events).

docs.title: runOnJS
docs.description: When you call a function on UI thread you can't be sure if you call a worklet or a callback from JS thread. To make it more transparent we introduced runOnJS, which calls a callback asynchronously. An exception will be thrown if you call a JS callback without this function.

docs.title: useAnimatedGestureHandler
docs.description: This hook allows for defining worklet handlers that can serve in a process of handling gestures.

docs.title: useAnimatedProps
docs.description: This hook is a counterpart of useAnimatedStyle hook, but works for a non-style view properties.

docs.title: useAnimatedReaction
docs.description: useAnimatedReaction hook allows performing certain actions on some shared values' change. The key idea is, all of the shared values included in the first worklet are the inputs set. Every time any of those change both worklets are triggered in the order specified above. Also the second worklet may modify any shared values excluding those used in the first worklet.

docs.title: useAnimatedRef
docs.description: This hook provides extended functionality of a standard ref. You can assign it to some component like ` and then access the target component via animatedRef.current. Besides, on the UI thread animated reference also contains the view tag of the target. It can be accessed like this: const viewTag = animatedRef(). This comes handy when using native methods like scrollTo and measure`.

docs.title: useAnimatedScrollHandler
docs.description: This is a convenience hook that returns an event handler reference which can be used with React Native's scrollable components.

docs.title: useAnimatedStyle
docs.description: This hook is one of the main elements of the new Reanimated v2 API.

docs.title: useDerivedValue
docs.description: This hook allows for creating shared value reference that can change in response to updating of one or more other shared values.

docs.title: useSharedValue
docs.description: Use this hook to create a reference to a JavaScript value that can be shared with worklets.

docs.title: withDecay
docs.description: Starts a velocity based "scroll" animation.

docs.title: withDelay
docs.description: Allows for the provided animation to start with a specified delay.

docs.title: withRepeat
docs.description: Repeats the provided animation several times.

docs.title: withSequence
docs.description: Runs the provided animations in a sequence.

docs.title: withSpring
docs.description: Starts a spring-based animation.

docs.title: withTiming
docs.description: Starts a time based animation.

docs.title: Reanimated 2.x architecture
docs.description: Due to time constraints we weren't able to finish this page.

docs.title: Events
docs.description: In the real world nothing changes instantly–there is always something between the states. When we touch a book we don't expect it to open instantly on a certain page. To make mobile apps feel more natural to the user, we use animations to smoothen out user interactions with the app user interface.

docs.title: Installation
docs.description: Reanimated 2 is primarily built in C++ using Turbo Modules infrastructure which is not yet completely deployed in React Native (specifically on Android).

docs.title: Migrating from Reanimated 1.x
docs.description: Before you consider migrating, note that Reanimated 2 is an alpha release, and that we cannot guarantee the new API will remain unchanged before the stable release of version 2.

docs.title: Shared Values
docs.description: Shared Values are among fundamental concepts behind Reanimated 2.0.

docs.title: Testing with Jest
docs.description: Reanimated test mocks use web implementation of Reanimated2. Before you begin using Reanimated mocks you need some setup actions.

docs.title: Troubleshooting common problems
docs.description: TypeError: Cannot convert undefined value to object on someVariable._closure

docs.title: Web Support
docs.description: Since

docs.title: Worklets
docs.description: The ultimate goal of worklets was for them to define small pieces of JavaScript code that we run when updating view properties or reacting to events on the UI thread. A natural construct in JavaScript for such a purpose was a simple method. With Reanimated 2 we spawn a secondary JS context on the UI thread that then is able to run JavaScript functions. The only thing that is needed is for that function to have “worklet” directive at the top:

docs.title: About React Native Reanimated
docs.description: React Native's Animated library reimplemented.

docs.description: `js

docs.title: SpringUtils
docs.description: For developers' convenience, it's possible to use a different way of configuring spring animation which follows behavior known from React Native core.

docs.title: Timing
docs.description: `js

docs.title: Clock
docs.description: Original Animated API makes an "animation" object a first class citizen.

docs.title: Animated.Code
docs.description: Animated.Code component allows you to define reanimated nodes that you want to execute when their input nodes updates, but aren't necessarily strictly related to some view properties and hence it does not feel right to place them under translate or other prop of an Animated.View. This component renders null, so you can place it in any place you want in your render method. It is required that your code is put inside component as we rely on componentDidMount and componentWillUnmount callbacks to install and cleanup animated nodes. Note that the code you put is going to be executed only once. We currently have no way of telling if your code changes and so it will only be run in componentDidMount. If you wish for your reanimated nodes to be updated when the component updates, you can update the key property of the Animated.Code component, which will effectively unmount old and mount new versions of it in the React tree. You can provide dependencies key which works just like second argueent in useCode.

docs.title: Additional configuration
docs.description: Reanimated exports two functions that control which properties can be animated natively:

docs.title: Declarative Animation API
docs.description: Invoking animation differs from the way it is done when using the original Animated API.

docs.title: Event handling with reanimated nodes
docs.description: react-native-reanimated's new syntax is possible to be used with Animated.event. Instead of providing only a mapping from event fields to animated nodes, it is allowed to write a function that takes reanimated values map as an input and return a block (or any other reanimated function) that will be then used to handle the event.

docs.title: Examples
docs.description: The source code for the example (showcase) app is under the Example/ directory.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.description: Before you get started you should definitely familiarize yourself with the original Animated API. It will do you well to be comfortable with how animations are generally done in Animated. (Fun Fact: Reanimated is also backwards compatible with the Animated API. 🙌)

docs.title: Transitions
docs.description: Transitions is an experimental API distributed as a part of reanimated which serves the purpose of animating between two states of view hierarchy. It is conceptually similar to LayoutAnimation concept from react native but gives much better control of what and how is going to be animated.

docs.title: Value
docs.description: Animated.Value is a container for storing values. It's is initialized with new Value(0) constructor. For backward compatibility there are provided API for setting value after it has been initialized:

docs.title: View, Props, etc
docs.description: Follow the original Animated library guides to learn how values can be connected to View attributes.
